title: More than a million of Britain's poorest families cut off their own power because they can't afford the meter
text:
More than a million of Britain's poorest families cut off their own power because they can't afford the meter Watchdog reveals 1.6m energy prepayment customers 'self-disconnected' their supply at least once a year Share The report found some on the lowest incomes 'self-disconnected' their supply at least once a year (Photo: Getty) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
More than 1.5 million of Britain’s poorest families cut off their own power supply because they cannot afford to top up their meters, a watchdog reveals today. 
Industry regulators could “do more” to help rising numbers of vulnerable consumers in the energy, water and financial protection markets, the National Audit Office says. 
It found 1.6 million energy prepayment customers - often those on the lowest incomes - “self-disconnected” their supply at least once a year because they do not or cannot add cash to their meters. 
The NAO’s inquiry into how firms cater for vulnerable consumers also discovered that three million disabled people had been denied insurance or charged extra because of their conditions. 
Although the industries offer discounted prices for customers on low incomes, criteria for who qualified varied among companies, awareness could be low and uptake was uneven, the NAO warned. Read More Quit Big Six energy suppliers and your bills could fall to what they were in 2008 Some of Britain's poorest families are turning off their own supply (Photo: PA) 
And the Money Advice Service found in 2015 that 32% of UK adults would be unable to pay an unexpected £300 bill without cutting back on essentials, surging to 50% or more for those who were unemployed, receiving benefits or living in social housing. 
James Taylor, policy chief at disability charity Scope, said: “Too many disabled people are currently ill-served across a number of markets including energy and insurance, resulting in higher costs for essential goods and services. 
“Today’s report highlights that much more action is needed to protect disabled consumers and tackle the unfair extra costs many face. Scope research shows this can amount to a staggering £550 a month. 
“Whilst there has been some good progress, the Government and regulators across all markets need to do much more to support disabled people and increase awareness amongst businesses of how to better identify and serve disabled customers.” Read More Energy giant AREN'T ripping you off and DON'T make fat profits, claim former industry watchdogs Many families lack the cash to top up their pre-pay meters (Photo: Getty) 
NAO chief Amyas Morse said: “A significant number of vulnerable consumers are particularly susceptible to bad outcomes or experiences from regulated services such as energy, water, communications and financial services. 
“It can mean disproportionately high bills, lack of access or choice, and debt. 
“Regulators have improved their understanding of vulnerability, and have made some progress in working with their industries to improve support for vulnerable consumers. 
“Regulators and government, however, need to work closer together to clarify their respective responsibilities if overall support for vulnerable consumers is to be value for money.” 
The Lib Dems called for the industry watchdogs to be scrapped. Read More Thousands of households to see their WATER bills rise in April - the support schemes to help if you're struggling to pay The NAO says regulators should 'do more' to help those on low incomes (Photo: Image Source) 
MP John Pugh, who sits on the Commons Public Accounts Committee, said: “This damning report shows that millions of the poorest or most vulnerable are having to shell out hundreds of pounds more than they should for basic services like water or electricity. 
“This, the report shows, is pushing people to take desperate measures and into the arms of loan sharks. This spiral of debt is happening because of the lack of action from a government distracted by Brexit and a set of useless regulators. 
“ Theresa May talks about an energy price crackdown and building a shared society that helps everyone, yet what is she doing on this whole agenda? Nothing, it’s all talk and no action. 
“The question we have to ask today about our watchdogs is this - if the watchdog doesn’t bark, is it time to put it down?” Like us on Facebook
